trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A description of authorization in the Azure AD v2.0 app model, including scopes, permissions, and consent.
trans-unit.target: A description of authorization in the Azure AD v2.0 app model, including scopes, permissions, and consent.

trans-unit.source: Apps that integrate with Azure AD follow a particular authorization model that allows users to control how an app can access their data.
trans-unit.target: Apps that integrate with Azure AD follow a particular authorization model that allows users to control how an app can access their data.

trans-unit.source: In app model v2.0, the implementation of this authorization model has been updated, changing how an app must interact with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: In app model v2.0, the implementation of this authorization model has been updated, changing how an app must interact with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: This topic covers the basic concepts of this authorization model, including scopes, permissions, and consent.
trans-unit.target: This topic covers the basic concepts of this authorization model, including scopes, permissions, and consent.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: App model v2.0 implements the <linkText>OAuth 2.0</linkText><title></title> authorization protocol, which is a method for allowing a 3rd party app to access web-hosted resources on behalf of a user.
trans-unit.target: App model v2.0 implements the <linkText>OAuth 2.0</linkText><title></title> authorization protocol, which is a method for allowing a 3rd party app to access web-hosted resources on behalf of a user.

trans-unit.source: Any web-hosted resource that integrates with Azure AD will have a resource identifier, or App ID URI.
trans-unit.target: Any web-hosted resource that integrates with Azure AD will have a resource identifier, or App ID URI.

trans-unit.source: For example, some of Microsoft's web-hosted resources include:
trans-unit.target: For example, some of Microsoft's web-hosted resources include:

trans-unit.source: The Office 365 Unified Mail API: https://outlook.office.com
trans-unit.target: The Office 365 Unified Mail API: https://outlook.office.com

trans-unit.source: The Azure Resource Manager API: https://management.azure.com
trans-unit.target: The Azure Resource Manager API: https://management.azure.com

trans-unit.source: The Azure AD Graph API: https://graph.windows.net
trans-unit.target: The Azure AD Graph API: https://graph.windows.net

trans-unit.source: The same is true for any 3rd party resources that has integrated with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The same is true for any 3rd party resources that has integrated with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Any of these resources can also define a set of permissions that can be used to divide up the functionality of that resource into smaller chunks.
trans-unit.target: Any of these resources can also define a set of permissions that can be used to divide up the functionality of that resource into smaller chunks.

trans-unit.source: As an example, the Office 365 Unified Mail API has defined these basic permissions:
trans-unit.target: As an example, the Office 365 Unified Mail API has defined these basic permissions:

trans-unit.source: Read a user's mailbox
trans-unit.target: Read a user's mailbox

trans-unit.source: Write to a user's mailbox
trans-unit.target: Write to a user's mailbox

trans-unit.source: Send mail as a user
trans-unit.target: Send mail as a user

trans-unit.source: By defining these permissions, the resource can have fine-grained control over its data and how it is exposed to the outside world.
trans-unit.target: By defining these permissions, the resource can have fine-grained control over its data and how it is exposed to the outside world.

trans-unit.source: A 3rd party app can then request these permissions from an end user - and the end-user must approve the permissions before the app can act on their behalf.
trans-unit.target: A 3rd party app can then request these permissions from an end user - and the end-user must approve the permissions before the app can act on their behalf.

trans-unit.source: By chunking the resource's functionality into smaller permission sets, 3rd party apps can be built to request only the specific permissions that they need in order to perform their duty.
trans-unit.target: By chunking the resource's functionality into smaller permission sets, 3rd party apps can be built to request only the specific permissions that they need in order to perform their duty.

trans-unit.source: It also enables end users to know exactly how an app will use their data, so that they are more confident that the app is not behaving with malicious intent.
trans-unit.target: It also enables end users to know exactly how an app will use their data, so that they are more confident that the app is not behaving with malicious intent.

trans-unit.source: In Azure AD and OAuth, these permissions are known as scopes.
trans-unit.target: In Azure AD and OAuth, these permissions are known as scopes.

trans-unit.source: You may also see them referred to as oAuth2Permissions.
trans-unit.target: You may also see them referred to as oAuth2Permissions.

trans-unit.source: A scope is represented in Azure AD as a string value.
trans-unit.target: A scope is represented in Azure AD as a string value.

trans-unit.source: Sticking with the Office 365 Unified Mail API example, the scope value for each permission is:
trans-unit.target: Sticking with the Office 365 Unified Mail API example, the scope value for each permission is:

trans-unit.source: Read a user's mailbox: Mail.Read
trans-unit.target: Read a user's mailbox: Mail.Read

trans-unit.source: Write to a user's mailbox: Mail.ReadWrite
trans-unit.target: Write to a user's mailbox: Mail.ReadWrite

trans-unit.source: Send mail as a user: Mail.Send
trans-unit.target: Send mail as a user: Mail.Send

trans-unit.source: An app can request these permissions by specifying the scopes in requests to the v2.0 endpoint, as described below.
trans-unit.target: An app can request these permissions by specifying the scopes in requests to the v2.0 endpoint, as described below.

trans-unit.source: In an OpenID Connect or OAuth 2.0 authorization request, an app can request the permissions it needs using the scope query parameter.
trans-unit.target: In an OpenID Connect or OAuth 2.0 authorization request, an app can request the permissions it needs using the scope query parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example, when a user signs into an app, the app would send a request like the following (with line breaks for readability):
trans-unit.target: For example, when a user signs into an app, the app would send a request like the following (with line breaks for readability):

trans-unit.source: The scope parameter is a space-separated list of scopes that the app is requesting.
trans-unit.target: The scope parameter is a space-separated list of scopes that the app is requesting.

trans-unit.source: Each individual scope is indicated by appending the scope value to the resource's identifier (App ID URI).
trans-unit.target: Each individual scope is indicated by appending the scope value to the resource's identifier (App ID URI).

trans-unit.source: The above request indicates that the app needs permission to read the user's mailbox and send mail as the user.
trans-unit.target: The above request indicates that the app needs permission to read the user's mailbox and send mail as the user.

trans-unit.source: After the user enters their credentials, the v2.0 endpoint will check for a matching record of user consent.
trans-unit.target: After the user enters their credentials, the v2.0 endpoint will check for a matching record of user consent.

trans-unit.source: If the user has not consented to any of the requested permissions in the past, the v2.0 endpoint will ask the user to grant the requested permissions.
trans-unit.target: If the user has not consented to any of the requested permissions in the past, the v2.0 endpoint will ask the user to grant the requested permissions.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Work Account Consent Screenshot</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Work Account Consent Screenshot</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the user approves the permission, the consent will be recorded so that the user does not have to re-consent on subsequent sign-ins.
trans-unit.target: When the user approves the permission, the consent will be recorded so that the user does not have to re-consent on subsequent sign-ins.

trans-unit.source: Your app does not have to ask for every permission it needs upon initial user sign-in or sign-up.
trans-unit.target: Your app does not have to ask for every permission it needs upon initial user sign-in or sign-up.

trans-unit.source: Because you can specify scopes on a per-request basis, your app can perform "incremental consent", and choose when the best time to ask the user for consent will be.
trans-unit.target: Because you can specify scopes on a per-request basis, your app can perform "incremental consent", and choose when the best time to ask the user for consent will be.

trans-unit.source: There are a few common reasons that an app might not ask for all permissions at once:
trans-unit.target: There are a few common reasons that an app might not ask for all permissions at once:

trans-unit.source: Apps that need many permissions.
trans-unit.target: Apps that need many permissions.

trans-unit.source: If your app accesses many different resources and performs rich functionality at each one, the list of permissions your app needs can become long very quickly.
trans-unit.target: If your app accesses many different resources and performs rich functionality at each one, the list of permissions your app needs can become long very quickly.

trans-unit.source: Historically, long lists of permissions have discouraged users from signing up for an app and decreased user adoption.
trans-unit.target: Historically, long lists of permissions have discouraged users from signing up for an app and decreased user adoption.

trans-unit.source: Instead of asking for these permissions all at once, your app can ask for a subset upon initial sign-in, and then incrementally ask for additional permissions as the user attempts to use advanced features.
trans-unit.target: Instead of asking for these permissions all at once, your app can ask for a subset upon initial sign-in, and then incrementally ask for additional permissions as the user attempts to use advanced features.

trans-unit.source: Apps that grow over time.
trans-unit.target: Apps that grow over time.

trans-unit.source: Almost every app begins with a smaller set of functionality and grow over time to incorporate new features.
trans-unit.target: Almost every app begins with a smaller set of functionality and grow over time to incorporate new features.

trans-unit.source: With incremental consent, you can easily make changes to your app and smoothly request new permissions from the user.
trans-unit.target: With incremental consent, you can easily make changes to your app and smoothly request new permissions from the user.

trans-unit.source: You simply update your code to send additional scopes in authorization requests.
trans-unit.target: You simply update your code to send additional scopes in authorization requests.

trans-unit.source: Admin-Only permissions. Some resources will define permissions that only an organization's administrator can consent to, or approve. For example, the Azure AD Graph API defines the Directory.Write permission, which allows an app to create, update, and delete users & groups, amognst other things. You can imagine why that permission might require approval from a highly privileged admin. By using incremental consent, your app can expose a basic set of functionality that any user can sign up for without an admin's approval. However, once they attempt to perform a highly-privileged action, you can request the admin-only permission and require that an admin signs up before accessing that portion of your app.
trans-unit.target: Admin-Only permissions. Some resources will define permissions that only an organization's administrator can consent to, or approve. For example, the Azure AD Graph API defines the Directory.Write permission, which allows an app to create, update, and delete users & groups, amognst other things. You can imagine why that permission might require approval from a highly privileged admin. By using incremental consent, your app can expose a basic set of functionality that any user can sign up for without an admin's approval. However, once they attempt to perform a highly-privileged action, you can request the admin-only permission and require that an admin signs up before accessing that portion of your app.

trans-unit.source: After the user consents to permissions for your app, your app can acquire access tokens that represent your app's permission to access a resource in some capacity.
trans-unit.target: After the user consents to permissions for your app, your app can acquire access tokens that represent your app's permission to access a resource in some capacity.

trans-unit.source: A given access token can only be used for a single resorce, but encoded inside it will be every permission that your app has been granted for that resource.
trans-unit.target: A given access token can only be used for a single resorce, but encoded inside it will be every permission that your app has been granted for that resource.

trans-unit.source: To acquire an access token, your app can make a request to the v2.0 token endpoint:
trans-unit.target: To acquire an access token, your app can make a request to the v2.0 token endpoint:

trans-unit.source: The resulting access token can then be used in HTTP requests to the resource - it will reliably indicate to the resource that your app has the proper permission to perform a given task.
trans-unit.target: The resulting access token can then be used in HTTP requests to the resource - it will reliably indicate to the resource that your app has the proper permission to perform a given task.

trans-unit.source: For more detail on the OAuth 2.0 protocol and how to acquire access tokens, see the <linkText>app model v2.0 protocol reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more detail on the OAuth 2.0 protocol and how to acquire access tokens, see the <linkText>app model v2.0 protocol reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The app model v2.0 has two well defined scopes that do not apply to a particular resource - openid and offline_access.
trans-unit.target: The app model v2.0 has two well defined scopes that do not apply to a particular resource - openid and offline_access.

trans-unit.source: If an app performs sign-in using OpenID Connect, it must request the openid scope.
trans-unit.target: If an app performs sign-in using OpenID Connect, it must request the openid scope.

trans-unit.source: The openid scope will show up in the work account consent screen as the "Sign you in" permission, and in the personal Microsoft account consent screen as the "View your profile and connect to apps and services using your Microsoft account" permission.
trans-unit.target: The openid scope will show up in the work account consent screen as the "Sign you in" permission, and in the personal Microsoft account consent screen as the "View your profile and connect to apps and services using your Microsoft account" permission.

trans-unit.source: This permission enables an app to access the OpenID Connect user info endpoint, and thus requires user approval.
trans-unit.target: This permission enables an app to access the OpenID Connect user info endpoint, and thus requires user approval.

trans-unit.source: The openid scope can also be used at the v2.0 token endpoint to acquire id_tokens, which can be used to secure HTTP calls between different components of an app.
trans-unit.target: The openid scope can also be used at the v2.0 token endpoint to acquire id_tokens, which can be used to secure HTTP calls between different components of an app.

trans-unit.source: The offline_access scope allows your app to access resources on behalf of the user for an extended period of time.
trans-unit.target: The offline_access scope allows your app to access resources on behalf of the user for an extended period of time.

trans-unit.source: In the work account consent screen, this scope will appear as the "Access your data anytime" permission.
trans-unit.target: In the work account consent screen, this scope will appear as the "Access your data anytime" permission.

trans-unit.source: In the personal Microsoft account consent screen, it will appear as the "Access your info anytime" permission.
trans-unit.target: In the personal Microsoft account consent screen, it will appear as the "Access your info anytime" permission.

trans-unit.source: When a user approves the offline_access scope, your app will be enabled to receive refresh tokens from the v2.0 token endpoint.
trans-unit.target: When a user approves the offline_access scope, your app will be enabled to receive refresh tokens from the v2.0 token endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Refresh tokens are long-lived and allow your app to acquire new access tokens as older ones expire.
trans-unit.target: Refresh tokens are long-lived and allow your app to acquire new access tokens as older ones expire.

trans-unit.source: If your app does not request the offline_access scope, it will not receive refresh_tokens.
trans-unit.target: If your app does not request the offline_access scope, it will not receive refresh_tokens.

trans-unit.source: This means that when you redeem an authorizationcode in the [OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#oauth2-authorization-code-flow), you will only receive back an accesstoken from the /token endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This means that when you redeem an authorizationcode in the [OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#oauth2-authorization-code-flow), you will only receive back an accesstoken from the /token endpoint.

trans-unit.source: That access_token will remain valid for a short period of time (typically one hour), but will eventually expire.
trans-unit.target: That access_token will remain valid for a short period of time (typically one hour), but will eventually expire.

trans-unit.source: At that point in time, your app will need to redirect the user back to the /authorize endpoint to retrieve a new authorization_code.
trans-unit.target: At that point in time, your app will need to redirect the user back to the /authorize endpoint to retrieve a new authorization_code.

trans-unit.source: During this redirect, the user may or may not need to enter their credentials again or re-consent to permissions, depending on the the type of app.
trans-unit.target: During this redirect, the user may or may not need to enter their credentials again or re-consent to permissions, depending on the the type of app.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to get and use refresh tokens, refer to the <linkText>app model v2.0 protocol reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to get and use refresh tokens, refer to the <linkText>app model v2.0 protocol reference</linkText><title></title>.
